resources.string: 30 Days of Tomatoes
30 Days of Tomato Tips
Day
Pick the right place

Tomatoes like sun. For optimal development they need min. 8 hours a day. Other than that you can plant them in the garden, in the greenhouse, on the balcony or in the tunnel. As long as it gets enough sun, sky is the limit :)
Pick the right time
If you\'re planting outside wait until after last frost date (in my region it\'s 15th May). If you\'re growing your plants inside you can start bit earlier.
Ensure healthy soil

Tomatoes like fertile, nutrient-rich soil nourishing soil that retains moisture. It would be best if it was sandy and clay. Additionally, feel free to enrich it with compost or manure. PH level should be between 6.0 and 7.0.
Choose the right variety
Select a tomato variety that suits your climate, available space, and personal preferences (e.g., determinate vs. indeterminate).
Consider companion plants

You\'ve probably heard that some plants shouldn\'t be growing next to each other, because they attract pests or fight for nutrients with each other. But there is also opposite effect - some plants go very well together. Great companion plants for tomatoes are: onion, carrots, basil, marigold, garlic, bean, lettuce and parsley.
Plant deep
Bury the tomato plant deep in the soil. This encourages a strong root system.
Provide adequate spacing
Allow 50 cm of space between each tomato plant for proper air circulation.
Stake or cage your plants
This supports the growing plants and prevents sprawling, which can lead to disease and pest issues.
Mulch around the base
Mulch helps regulate soil temperature, conserves moisture, and reduces weeds.
Water consistently
Tomatoes prefer consistent, even watering. Avoid overhead watering to prevent fungal diseases.
Avoid watering the leaves
Water at the base of the plant to prevent fungal diseases.
Prune suckers
Remove the small shoots that develop in the leaf axils to direct energy toward fruit production.
Fertilize judiciously
Avoid over-fertilizing, which can lead to excess foliage and fewer fruits.
Provide support for heavy fruits
Use slings or netting to support large or heavy fruit to prevent branches from breaking.
Prune leaves near the ground
This improves air circulation and reduces the risk of soil-borne diseases.
Monitor soil moisture levels
Stick your finger into the soil to check for moisture. Water when the top 3cm is dry.
Hand-pollinate if necessary
In some cases, particularly in greenhouses or areas with limited insect activity, you may need to hand-pollinate to ensure fruit set.
Thin out excess foliage
This helps improve air circulation and allows more sunlight to reach the fruits.
Be mindful of temperature extremes
Tomatoes are sensitive to both high and low temperatures. Provide shade during heatwaves and consider covering plants during unexpected frosts.
Monitor for blossom end rot
Ensure consistent watering to prevent this common tomato ailment.
Use the right type of fertilizer

In the initial phase of tomato growth (vegetative), i.e. from planting to the first flowers, fertilizer should contain similar proportions of nitrogen, phosphorus and potassium, enriched with additional micro-elements, such as magnesium, sulfur and iron.
Switch to fertilizer for generative phase

In the later (generative) phase, i.e. after the appearance of flowers until the end of fruiting, you should switch to another fertilizer, because that\'s when tomato\'s needs change. Choose one that contains predominant amount of potassium, but it also should have some phosphorus and nitrogen.
Monitor for pests and diseases
Sadly, there are plenty of dangers waiting for your tomatoes - pests, bacterias, virus and fungal diseases. It\'s crucial to learn to identify them and to act quickly whenever problems emerge.
Harvest ripe tomatoes gently
Handle tomatoes carefully to avoid bruising or damaging the fruit.
Pinch the tops
Once the plant reaches its desired height, pinch off the growing tip to encourage fruit production.
Harvest unripe tomatoes before frost
If frost is imminent, pick green tomatoes and allow them to ripen indoors.
Save seeds

If you have heirloom varieties or liked some variety very much, consider saving seeds for future plantings. Bear in mind though that hybrid varieties (F1) most likely won\'t produce fruits with the same characteristics
Keep records
Document your planting dates, varieties, and any issues faced. This information will be valuable for future seasons.
Rotate crops
Avoid planting tomatoes in the same spot every year to prevent soil-borne diseases.
Enjoy gardening
Last but not the least, have fun and don\'t stress to much. Homegrown tomatoes taste way better than supermarket ones, so take your time to enjoy them!
